title-group.subtitle: Botulinum Toxin Induces Chemodenervation of Intrafusal and Extrafusal Fibers

body.p:
We thank Phadke et al for their comments on our article1 and congratulate them for suggesting a method of examining the intrafusal effects of botulinum toxin injection. Indeed, we focused on the effects of botulinum toxin on the muscle spindle and on the fusimotor drive on our article. We agree that an accurate estimation of the intrafusal effects of botulinum toxin injection is needed. Phadke et al2 have proposed that it is possible to isolate these effects and thereby subtract the percentage change in H-reflex amplitude from baseline from the percentage change in Achilles tendon reflex amplitude from baseline. These authors have expressed the view that the decreased Achilles tendon reflex amplitude reflects the central, intrafusal, and extrafusal effects, and that the decreased H-reflex amplitude reflects only the central and extrafusal effects, following a botulinum toxin injection. Hence, Phadke and colleagues have proposed a new formula involving the H-reflex and Achilles tendon reflex amplitudes that we believe would be a good method for assessing the intrafusal effects of botulinum toxin injection. We would like to see this formula widely adopted by clinicians. Below are our specific responses the first three comments of Phadke et al.
Although we did not mention this issue in our study, we agree that the decreased compound motor action potential amplitude reflects only the extrafusal effects of the botulinum toxin injection. Therefore, the compound motor action potential amplitude does not reflect the whole effects of botulinum toxin.
There was a lack of clarity with regard to some of the data presented in Table 2 of our article, for which we apologize. We applied only an ankle modified Tardieu Scale because its reliability in the ankle muscle is superior to that in the knee.3 KE and KF on Table 2 indicate the position of knee joint; knee extension and knee flexion, and the modified Tardieu Scale was assessed for the ankle joint as described in the Methods section and in the tables in our article.
We agree that this formula suggested by Phadke et al represents a novel method of assessing the intrafusal effects of botulinum toxin injection. We would indeed be interested in reassessing our results using this formula in a future study.
